snippet: A growing number of states and cities are working to keep ex-offenders with minor convictions from being shut out of the job market.
abstract: Editorial praises laws or administrative directives that bar employers from asking about job applicants' criminal histories until applicants reach interview stage or receive conditional job offer; holds such measures are propelled in part by concerns about civic damage that results from shutting otherwise qualified people out of job market, and in some cases driving them back to crime.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of states and cities are working to keep ex-offenders with minor convictions from being shut out of the job market.
